\/D:\/repos\/rr\/source\/ReleaseNotes\/R: The Xenko game engine has been renamed to Stride.
The Xenko game engine has been renamed to Stride.
From now on, all source code, blogs, and tutorials will use the name ‘Stride’ instead of ‘Xenko’.
From now on, all source code, blogs, and tutorials will use the name ‘Stride’ instead of ‘Xenko’.
More details available on the <g1>dedicated blog post</g1>
More details available on the <g1>dedicated blog post</g1>
Thanks to a substantial contribution from Sean Boettger and sponsored by David Jeske, Stride now supports Voxel Cone Tracing GI!
Thanks to a substantial contribution from Sean Boettger and sponsored by David Jeske, Stride now supports Voxel Cone Tracing GI!

Stride editor and toolchain is now running with .NET 5!
Stride editor and toolchain is now running with .NET 5!
Runtime has been working with .NET Core for a few versions already.
Runtime has been working with .NET Core for a few versions already.
This allows us to have scripts and custom assets in a project targetting <g1>.NET Standard 2.1</g1> or <g2>.NET 5</g2>.
This allows us to have scripts and custom assets in a project targetting <g1>.NET Standard 2.1</g1> or <g2>.NET 5</g2>.
If you have scripts or custom assets in a .NET Framework project rather than a .NET Standard project, you can still choose between <g1>.NET 5</g1> and <g2>.NET Framework</g2> within the launcher:
If you have scripts or custom assets in a .NET Framework project rather than a .NET Standard project, you can still choose between <g1>.NET 5</g1> and <g2>.NET Framework</g2> within the launcher:
The framework will also be displayed in the Game Studio toolbar for easier identification while both coexist.
The framework will also be displayed in the Game Studio toolbar for easier identification while both coexist.
.NET Framework version can be considered deprecated and will likely be removed in a future release (likely 4.1) to allow us to take full advantage of <g1>C# 8.0</g1> and soon-to-come <g2>C# 9.0</g2>.
.NET Framework version can be considered deprecated and will likely be removed in a future release (likely 4.1) to allow us to take full advantage of <g1>C# 8.0</g1> and soon-to-come <g2>C# 9.0</g2>.

We also expect dropping .NET Framework and supporting only .NET 5 will greatly simplify our installation process since we won't depend on specific workloads or packages of Visual Studio being installed anymore.

We also expect dropping .NET Framework and supporting only .NET 5 will greatly simplify our installation process since we won't depend on specific workloads or packages of Visual Studio being installed anymore.
This was a recurring issue with our users.

Thanks to another big community contribution sponsored by <g1>vvvv</g1>, Stride now supports GPU instancing per model.
Thanks to another big community contribution sponsored by <g1>vvvv</g1>, Stride now supports GPU instancing per model.
The nice thing about it is, that it plays together with the entity-component system:
The nice thing about it is, that it plays together with the entity-component system:
Simply add an Instancing component to an entity with a model.
Simply add an Instancing component to an entity with a model.
Then you can choose between 3 ways of how you generate the instances:
Then you can choose between 3 ways of how you generate the instances:
<g1>EntityTransform</g1>, uses the transformation of other entities with an Instance component.
<g1>EntityTransform</g1>, uses the transformation of other entities with an Instance component.
This allows you to add components like physics, audio, etc. to each instance.
This allows you to add components like physics, audio, etc. to each instance.
<g1>UserArray</g1>, for providing an array of matrices via script
<g1>UserArray</g1>, for providing an array of matrices via script
<g1>UserBuffer</g1>, for providing a structured buffer (GPU resource) of matrices via script
<g1>UserBuffer</g1>, for providing a structured buffer (GPU resource) of matrices via script
<g1>UserArray</g1> and <g2>UserBuffer</g2> even allow you to specify how the matrix is multiplied with the parent transformation.
<g1>UserArray</g1> and <g2>UserBuffer</g2> even allow you to specify how the matrix is multiplied with the parent transformation.
Picking individual instances in Game Studio works as well and selects the entity with the respective Instance component.
Picking individual instances in Game Studio works as well and selects the entity with the respective Instance component.
There are also two new entity templates for easy setup:
There are also two new entity templates for easy setup:

Graphics API: different selection mechanism + Vulkan improvements
Graphics API: different selection mechanism + Vulkan improvements
There's been a big overhaul on Stride build system to make Graphics API selection work in a more future-proof way.
There's been a big overhaul on Stride build system to make Graphics API selection work in a more future-proof way.
It was previously relying on the custom <g1>RuntimeIdentifier</g1> being set in the solution.
It was previously relying on the custom <g1>RuntimeIdentifier</g1> being set in the solution.
This didn't work very well because it was completely orthogonal to the existing <g2>RuntimeIdentifier</g2>, and sometimes not having good fallbacks.
This didn't work very well because it was completely orthogonal to the existing <g2>RuntimeIdentifier</g2>, and sometimes not having good fallbacks.
From now on, the user project will use <g1>StrideGraphicsApi</g1> in the <g2>.csproj</g2> project file to specify the graphics API.
From now on, the user project will use <g1>StrideGraphicsApi</g1> in the <g2>.csproj</g2> project file to specify the graphics API.
We hope to expose this in the editor later.
We hope to expose this in the editor later.

We also took the opportunity to improve the state of Vulkan renderer (thanks to a switch to <g1>Vortice.Vulkan bindings</g1> from <g2>Amer Koleci</g2>) and automatize graphics unit tests, currently running for D3D11 and Vulkan.

We also took the opportunity to improve the state of Vulkan renderer (thanks to a switch to <g1>Vortice.Vulkan bindings</g1> from <g2>Amer Koleci</g2>) and automatize graphics unit tests, currently running for D3D11 and Vulkan.
It's still a work in progress so expect more in future releases.
It's still a work in progress so expect more in future releases.
The first 10 C# beginner tutorials are recorded and uploaded to the official Stride Youtube channel.
The first 10 C# beginner tutorials are recorded and uploaded to the official Stride Youtube channel.

These videos are the video equivalent of the existing <g1>online documentation</g1> for the C# beginner template tutorials and the 'new project' template when creating a new project from the Stride launcher.

These videos are the video equivalent of the existing <g1>online documentation</g1> for the C# beginner template tutorials and the 'new project' template when creating a new project from the Stride launcher.
The C# beginner series should be fully recorded by the end of July 2020.
The C# beginner series should be fully recorded by the end of July 2020.
After those videos are done, Jorn will put his focus on the C# Intermediate project template.
After those videos are done, Jorn will put his focus on the C# Intermediate project template.

The Stride GitHub repository has more closed pull requests than open issues.
The Stride GitHub repository has more closed pull requests than open issues.
